Both cases required cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) and immediate discontinuation of the surgery. One patient was successfully resuscitated and underwent a revision surgery without further complications. The other patient, unfortunately, did not respond to CPR and succumbed to the cardiac arrest. Possible contributing factors include the release of emboli from the bone cement, hemodynamic instability, and anesthesia-related cardiovascular effects. Pre-operative risk assessment, vigilant hemodynamic monitoring, awareness of potential complications, and prompt CPR are crucial in managing such emergencies. A multidisciplinary approach involving surgeons, anesthesiologists, and cardiologists is necessary to minimize the risk and optimize patient outcomes in similar cases.

Early magnetic resonance imaging in acute traumatic internuclear ophthalmoplegia. Acute traumatic internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO) is a rare condition characterized by impaired horizontal eye movement due to disruption of the medial longitudinal fasciculus. This study aimed to investigate the utility of early magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) in diagnosing acute traumatic INO. 10 patients with clinically diagnosed acute traumatic INO underwent MRI within 72 hours of injury. MRI findings revealed abnormal signal intensity in the medial longitudinal fasciculus in all patients, confirming the diagnosis of acute traumatic INO. Early MRI provides valuable diagnostic information for acute traumatic INO, allowing for prompt identification and management of this condition. Further studies are needed to assess the long-term outcomes and treatment responses in patients with acute traumatic INO.

A study of the comparative efficacy of four common analgesics in the control of postsurgical dental pain. This study aimed to compare the efficacy of four common analgesics - ibuprofen, acetaminophen, diclofenac, and tramadol - in the control of postsurgical dental pain. 60 patients who underwent dental extraction were randomly assigned to receive one of the four analgesics. Pain intensity was assessed using a visual analogue scale at 1, 2, 4, 6, and 8 hours post-administration. The results showed that all four analgesics significantly reduced pain compared to baseline. Ibuprofen and diclofenac showed the greatest reduction in pain intensity at all time points. Acetaminophen and tramadol also demonstrated significant pain reduction, but to a lesser extent. These findings can guide clinicians in selecting appropriate analgesics for postsurgical dental pain management.

Partial duplication of the face: case report and review. Partial duplication of the face is a rare congenital anomaly characterized by the presence of duplicated facial structures. We present a case report of a 3-year-old male with partial duplication of the face, involving the forehead, eyes, nose, and upper lip. The patient had no systemic abnormalities and normal neurological development. A comprehensive review of the literature was performed to identify similar cases and discuss the etiology, clinical presentation, and management options. The exact cause of partial duplication of the face remains unknown, but it is believed to result from abnormal midline facial development during embryogenesis. Surgical intervention may be considered for functional and cosmetic purposes, but outcomes vary. Overall, partial duplication of the face is a complex anomaly that requires multidisciplinary evaluation and individualized treatment.

Tryptophan-induced eosinophilia-myalgia syndrome Eight patients who became ill while taking tryptophan had myalgia, fatigue, rash, fever, edema, alopecia, arthralgias, diminished joint motion, skin tightening, muscle cramping, and distal paresthesias. Tryptophan-induced eosinophilia-myalgia syndrome (EMS) is a rare but serious condition associated with the use of tryptophan supplements. This case series describes eight patients who experienced various symptoms after taking tryptophan, including myalgia, fatigue, rash, fever, edema, alopecia, arthralgias, diminished joint motion, skin tightening, muscle cramping, and distal paresthesias. EMS is characterized by eosinophilia, myalgia, and various systemic symptoms, which can be severe and debilitating. Prompt recognition and discontinuation of tryptophan supplementation are crucial for preventing further complications. Treatment primarily involves supportive care and symptomatic management. Awareness of this syndrome is important for clinicians to consider in patients presenting with eosinophilia and multi-systemic symptoms, particularly those who have recently started or increased their tryptophan intake.

Amiloride blocks the onset of ACTH-induced hypertension in the sheep. Amiloride, a potassium-sparing diuretic, has been shown to effectively prevent the development of ACTH-induced hypertension in sheep. This study aimed to investigate the underlying mechanisms by examining the effects of amiloride on plasma renin activity (PRA), aldosterone levels, and sodium balance. The results demonstrated that amiloride blocked the increase in both PRA and aldosterone levels normally observed during ACTH-induced hypertension. Additionally, amiloride prevented the sodium retention typically associated with this condition. These findings suggest that amiloride exerts its antihypertensive effects by inhibiting the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system and enhancing sodium excretion. Further research is warranted to better understand the specific pathways involved and to determine if amiloride could be a potential therapeutic option for treating ACTH-induced hypertension in humans.

Imaging the fetal brain in the second and third trimesters using transvaginal sonography. Transvaginal sonography has emerged as a viable option for imaging the fetal brain during the second and third trimesters of pregnancy. This study aimed to investigate the feasibility and efficacy of transvaginal sonography in visualizing and assessing the fetal brain development during these critical periods. A total of 100 pregnant women were enrolled, with transvaginal sonography performed at regular intervals throughout their pregnancies. The images obtained were then analyzed by experienced radiologists for the presence of anatomical structures and abnormalities in the fetal brain. Results showed that transvaginal sonography provided clear and detailed images of the fetal brain, allowing for accurate measurement and assessment of brain structures. Moreover, the technique allowed for early detection of certain abnormalities, leading to timely intervention and management. These findings suggest that transvaginal sonography can serve as a valuable tool in the prenatal evaluation of the fetal brain, potentially improving prenatal diagnosis and counseling. Further studies are warranted to validate these findings and explore additional applications of transvaginal sonography in fetal brain imaging.

Tumefactive fibroinflammatory lesions of the head and neck. Tumefactive fibroinflammatory lesions (TFIL) of the head and neck are rare and poorly understood conditions. This study aimed to report the clinical and pathological features of TFIL and investigate its management outcomes. Twenty-three patients with TFIL were reviewed retrospectively, with a mean age of 46.4 years. The most commonly affected site was the parotid gland. Histopathological analysis revealed fibroinflammatory changes with lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate and occasional eosinophils. Management options included surgical excision, corticosteroid therapy, and/or observation. All patients showed clinical improvement after treatment, with no cases of recurrence during the follow-up period. Further research is needed to better understand the etiology and optimal treatment strategies for TFIL.

Isolated lung transplantation for pulmonary fibrosis. Isolated lung transplantation is a potential treatment option for patients with pulmonary fibrosis. This retrospective study aimed to evaluate the outcomes of isolated lung transplantation in patients with pulmonary fibrosis. A total of 100 patients who underwent isolated lung transplantation for pulmonary fibrosis were included in the study. The primary endpoints were patient survival, graft survival, and functional outcomes following transplantation. The overall survival rate at 1 year was 80%, and the 5-year survival rate was 60%. Graft survival rates were 75% and 50% at 1 year and 5 years, respectively. Functional outcomes, including lung function and exercise capacity, significantly improved following transplantation. Complication rates were relatively low, with the most common complications being infection and rejection. In conclusion, isolated lung transplantation is a viable treatment option for patients with pulmonary fibrosis, offering improved survival and functional outcomes.

Empiric treatment of fungal infections in the neutropenic host. Fungal infections are a major cause of morbidity and mortality in neutropenic patients. Empiric treatment strategies aim to prevent invasive fungal infections in this high-risk population. This retrospective study evaluated the efficacy of empiric antifungal treatment in neutropenic patients with suspected fungal infections. 

Data from 150 neutropenic patients with suspected fungal infections were analyzed. The majority of patients (75%) received empiric antifungal therapy, while the remaining patients received no antifungal treatment. 

Results showed a significantly lower incidence of proven or probable invasive fungal infections in the treatment group compared to the non-treatment group (15% vs. 30%, p<0.05). In addition, there was a lower mortality rate in the treatment group (10% vs. 20%, p<0.05).

Among the treated patients, the most commonly used antifungal agents were fluconazole and voriconazole. Both drugs demonstrated good efficacy in preventing fungal infections, with no significant difference in outcomes between the two agents.

Overall, empiric antifungal therapy in neutropenic patients with suspected fungal infections was associated with a lower incidence of invasive fungal infections and improved survival. These findings support the use of empiric antifungal treatment in this vulnerable patient population. Further studies are warranted to optimize treatment strategies and explore the use of newer antifungal agents.

Association of Treacher Collins syndrome and translocation 6p21. 31/16p13. 11: exclusion of the locus from these candidate regions. Treacher Collins syndrome (TCS) is a rare genetic disorder characterized by craniofacial anomalies. Previous studies have suggested that the syndrome may be associated with a translocation between the 6p21.31 and 16p13.11 regions of the genome. In this study, we aimed to confirm or exclude the involvement of these candidate regions in TCS. 

Using a combination of cytogenetic techniques, including G-banding and fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH), we analyzed samples from 42 patients with clinically diagnosed TCS. We found no evidence of the translocation in any of the patients, indicating that the involvement of the 6p21.31 and 16p13.11 regions can be excluded as a cause of TCS. 

These findings suggest that other genetic abnormalities or environmental factors may play a role in the development of TCS. Further research is needed to identify these factors and improve our understanding of the etiology of this syndrome.

The role of antihistamine therapy in vascular headaches. Vascular headaches, such as migraines and cluster headaches, can be debilitating and challenging to manage. While various treatment options exist, the role of antihistamine therapy in alleviating vascular headaches is still debated. This article provides a critical review of the available evidence regarding the efficacy of antihistamines in the management of vascular headaches. The underlying pathophysiological mechanisms involved in these headaches, including histamine release, are discussed. The potential benefits and drawbacks of antihistamine therapy, including their sedative effects and potential interactions with other medications, are examined. Furthermore, the current guidelines and recommendations for the use of antihistamines in treating vascular headaches are presented. This comprehensive analysis aims to provide clinicians with a better understanding of the role of antihistamines in vascular headache management and guide their decision-making process when considering this therapeutic option.

The value of push-type jejunal endoscopy in familial adenomatosis coli/Gardner's syndrome. Familial adenomatosis coli (FAP), also known as Gardner's syndrome, is an inherited condition characterized by the development of numerous colorectal polyps. The efficacy of push-type jejunal endoscopy in diagnosing and monitoring FAP/Gardner's syndrome was investigated in a study involving 57 patients. The endoscopic examination revealed the presence of jejunal polyps in 51 patients (89.5%). The polyp burden was found to be significantly higher in patients with a positive family history of FAP/Gardner's syndrome compared to those without a family history. The push-type jejunal endoscopy allowed for targeted biopsies and the identification of polyps for subsequent treatment. Follow-up endoscopies showed a reduction in the number and size of jejunal polyps in patients who underwent surgical intervention. Thus, push-type jejunal endoscopy can be a valuable tool for the diagnosis and management of FAP/Gardner's syndrome.

Uniparental paternal disomy in Angelman's syndrome. Angelman's syndrome is a neurodevelopmental disorder caused by a genetic mutation on chromosome 15. We conducted a study to investigate the frequency and clinical features associated with uniparental paternal disomy in Angelman's syndrome. We analyzed a cohort of 50 patients diagnosed with Angelman's syndrome and identified five cases (10%) with uniparental paternal disomy. These patients exhibited more severe symptoms, including more profound developmental delay, severe intellectual disability, and a higher prevalence of seizures compared to patients without uniparental paternal disomy. Our findings suggest that uniparental paternal disomy may be associated with a more severe phenotype in Angelman's syndrome. This information is important for genetic counseling and could help guide the management and treatment of patients with this disorder. Further research is needed to understand the underlying mechanisms and potential therapeutic implications of uniparental paternal disomy in Angelman's syndrome.

Primary orchiectomy versus estrogen therapy in advanced prostatic cancer--a randomized study: results after 7 to 10 years of followup. In this randomized study, the efficacy of primary orchidectomy versus estrogen therapy in advanced prostatic cancer was compared. The results after 7 to 10 years of follow-up were analyzed. A total of 250 patients were enrolled in the study, with 125 patients in each treatment group. It was found that both treatment modalities resulted in similar overall survival rates, with no statistically significant difference between the groups. However, there were differences in the side effect profiles. Patients who underwent orchidectomy experienced a higher incidence of hot flashes and erectile dysfunction, while patients on estrogen therapy had a higher incidence of thromboembolic events and gynecomastia. Furthermore, quality of life assessments revealed that patients on estrogen therapy reported better sexual function and less psychological distress compared to those who underwent orchidectomy. These findings suggest that both primary orchidectomy and estrogen therapy are effective treatment options for advanced prostatic cancer, and the choice should be based on individual patient preferences and concerns regarding side effects.

CD34 antigen expression in children with Philadelphia chromosome-positive acute lymphoblastic leukemia. Philadelphia chromosome-positive acute lymphoblastic leukemia (Ph+ ALL) is a subtype of ALL characterized by the presence of the Philadelphia chromosome resulting from a translocation between chromosomes 9 and 22. The CD34 antigen is known to be expressed on early hematopoietic progenitor cells and is commonly used as a marker for leukemia cells. However, the expression of CD34 antigen in Ph+ ALL remains controversial. In this study, we investigated the expression of CD34 antigen in children with Ph+ ALL. Flow cytometric analysis of bone marrow samples revealed CD34 antigen expression in 80% of Ph+ ALL cases, suggesting that CD34 antigen may serve as a potential therapeutic target for this aggressive subtype of ALL. Further research is needed to elucidate the role of CD34 antigen in the pathogenesis and treatment response of Ph+ ALL.

Transient entrapment neuropathy of the posterior interosseous nerve in violin players. Transient entrapment neuropathy of the posterior interosseous nerve (PIN) in violin players is a rare condition characterized by acute muscle weakness and pain in the forearm and hand. This study aims to describe the clinical and radiological findings of four cases of PIN entrapment neuropathy in professional violinists. All patients presented with worsening forearm pain and weakness while playing the violin. Neurological examination revealed weakness and atrophy of the extensor muscles of the forearm and hand. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the affected forearm showed focal swelling and signal abnormalities around the PIN. Electromyography confirmed the diagnosis by demonstrating denervation changes in the extensor muscles. Non-operative treatment, including rest, physical therapy, and modification of playing techniques, led to significant improvement in symptoms in all cases. This study highlights the importance of considering PIN entrapment neuropathy as a potential cause of forearm and hand symptoms in violin players.

Ondansetron: a new entity in emesis control. Ondansetron is a novel drug that has emerged as an effective therapy for emesis control. It acts by blocking the serotonin receptors in the central nervous system, specifically the 5-HT3 receptor, preventing the onset of emesis. Ondansetron offers a significant advantage over traditional anti-emetic drugs, such as metoclopramide, in terms of its improved efficacy and reduced side effects. Clinical trials have demonstrated its efficacy in the prevention and treatment of chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting, as well as postoperative nausea and vomiting. Ondansetron has also shown promise in the management of other conditions associated with emesis, such as motion sickness and hyperemesis gravidarum. The availability of ondansetron as a safe and effective anti-emetic agent has revolutionized the treatment of emesis and has significantly improved the quality of life for patients undergoing chemotherapy or surgery.

Protective role of vitamin E in biological systems. Vitamin E, a potent antioxidant, has been shown to have beneficial effects in various biological systems. This review focuses on the protective role of vitamin E in these systems. It has been reported that vitamin E can prevent oxidative damage by scavenging free radicals and inhibiting lipid peroxidation. Additionally, it has anti-inflammatory properties and can modulate immune responses. In terms of cardiovascular health, vitamin E has been shown to reduce the risk of cardiovascular diseases by preventing oxidative stress and reducing inflammation. In the field of neuroprotection, vitamin E has been found to be neuroprotective by reducing oxidative damage and inflammation in the brain. Furthermore, vitamin E has been shown to have a protective role in other systems, such as the liver, kidney, and reproductive system. Overall, vitamin E has demonstrated its importance as a protective agent in various biological systems and its supplementation may be beneficial for maintaining optimal health.

Intravenous immunoglobulin treatment in patients with chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy. Chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (CIDP) is a demyelinating disorder of the peripheral nerves, characterized by progressive weakness and sensory loss. Intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIg) treatment has been proven effective in CIDP, but the optimal treatment regimen remains unknown. This study aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of IVIg in patients with CIDP.

A retrospective analysis was conducted on medical records of 50 CIDP patients who received IVIg treatment. Clinical response was assessed using the Medical Research Council (MRC) sum score and the Inflammatory Neuropathy Cause and Treatment (INCAT) disability score. Adverse events were also recorded.

Results showed that IVIg treatment led to a significant improvement in both MRC sum score and INCAT disability score. Approximately 80% of patients had a favorable response to IVIg treatment. Adverse events were mostly mild and transient, with headache being the most common. No serious adverse events were reported.

In conclusion, IVIg treatment is effective and safe for patients with CIDP. Further studies are needed to determine the optimal dosage and duration of treatment.

Interventional radiologic alternatives to cholecystectomy. Cholecystectomy is the standard treatment for symptomatic gallstones; however, it may not be feasible in certain cases. Interventional radiologic alternatives to cholecystectomy have been explored as less invasive options. This review aims to summarize the available evidence on these interventions. The most commonly utilized techniques include percutaneous cholecystostomy (PC), endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) with gallbladder stenting, and peroral cholecystoduodenoscopy (POCD). PC involves the percutaneous insertion of a catheter into the gallbladder for biliary decompression. ERCP with gallbladder stenting allows for endoscopic biliary drainage through the placement of a stent. POCD involves the endoscopic removal of gallstones through the duodenum. These interventions have shown promising outcomes in the management of acute cholecystitis, high surgical risk patients, and those with anatomical challenges. However, further studies are needed to determine long-term efficacy, complications, and patient satisfaction compared to cholecystectomy.

Short-term memory and sentence comprehension. This study aimed to assess the histopathologic changes after bladder-drained canine pancreas allograft transplantation. Sixteen dogs were included in the longitudinal open biopsy study. Early and nonspecific findings included edema, polymorph extravasation, and lymphocytes associated with focal parenchymal injury. The initial feature of rejection was endothelial changes in capillaries and small veins, along with perivascular inflammatory cell infiltration. Acinar cell loss was progressive, while islets and ducts were relatively preserved, suggesting that acinar tissue is more susceptible to lytic necrosis. Functional rejection, determined by fasting urinary amylase levels, indicated extensive and irreversible necrosis. Immunosuppressed dogs with functioning grafts showed minor and transient endothelial changes and no staining of parenchymal cells with class II antigens. This study provides vital information for the assessment of percutaneous biopsies in clinical pancreas transplant programs.

Primary osteosarcoma of the lung.  Report of two cases and review of the literature. We present two cases of primary osteosarcoma of the lung and review the current literature on this rare entity.  The first case was a 45-year-old male who presented with cough and hemoptysis. Radiological evaluation revealed a large mass in the right lung. Histopathology confirmed the diagnosis of osteosarcoma, characterized by the presence of malignant cells producing osteoid or immature bone matrix. The second case was a 52-year-old female who presented with dyspnea and chest pain. Imaging studies revealed a mass in the left lung, and biopsy confirmed the diagnosis of osteosarcoma. Both patients underwent surgical resection followed by chemotherapy. The literature review identified a total of 103 cases of primary pulmonary osteosarcoma reported to date. The majority of patients were middle-aged adults, with a slight male predominance. The most common presenting symptoms were cough, dyspnea, and chest pain. Prognosis was generally poor, with a median survival of 10-12 months. In conclusion, primary osteosarcoma of the lung is a rare and aggressive tumor with a poor prognosis. Early diagnosis and aggressive treatment are crucial for improving patient outcomes.

Diphenylhydantoin-induced hypogammaglobulinemia in a patient infected with human immunodeficiency virus. Hypogammaglobulinemia is a rare complication of diphenylhydantoin therapy. We report a case of a patient infected with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) who developed hypogammaglobulinemia while receiving diphenylhydantoin for the treatment of seizures. This patient experienced recurrent bacterial infections and a significant decline in CD4+ T cell count while on diphenylhydantoin. Discontinuation of diphenylhydantoin and initiation of intravenous immunoglobulin replacement therapy resulted in improvements in both immunoglobulin levels and CD4+ T cell count. This case highlights the importance of considering diphenylhydantoin-induced hypogammaglobulinemia in patients with HIV infection presenting with recurrent infections and declining CD4+ T cell counts.

Pelvic pain: lessons from anatomy and physiology. Pelvic pain is a common and debilitating condition with various etiologies. To better understand and manage pelvic pain, a comprehensive understanding of the anatomy and physiology of the pelvis is crucial. This review aims to elucidate the anatomical structures involved in pelvic pain, including the muscles, ligaments, nerves, and visceral organs. The potential sources of pelvic pain, such as endometriosis, pelvic inflammatory disease, and pelvic floor dysfunction, are discussed in relation to their anatomical locations. Furthermore, the physiological mechanisms underlying pelvic pain, including sensitization of nociceptive pathways and central nervous system involvement, are explored. By integrating knowledge of pelvic anatomy and physiology, healthcare providers can enhance their diagnostic and therapeutic approaches, leading to improved management and outcomes for patients with pelvic pain.

Dietary management of acute childhood diarrhea: optimal timing of feeding and appropriate use of milks and mixed diets. This review aimed to determine the optimal timing of feeding and appropriate use of milks and mixed diets in the dietary management of acute childhood diarrhea. Evidence from randomized controlled trials suggests that early refeeding, within 4-6 hours of initial presentation, is safe and beneficial for children with acute diarrhea. Exclusive breastfeeding or continued breastfeeding with additional fluids is recommended for infants under six months of age. For children over six months of age, the use of continued breastfeeding alongside a mixed diet with starchy foods, fruits, and vegetables is recommended. Certain milks, such as lactose-free or lactose-reduced cow's milk, can be used as an appropriate alternative to breast milk. Additionally, oral rehydration solutions should be given according to the age-appropriate recommended formula. The findings highlight the importance of appropriate feeding practices in the management of acute childhood diarrhea.

Small bowel phytobezoar mimicking presentation of Crohn's disease. We present a case of a 45-year-old male who presented with abdominal pain, nausea, and weight loss, suggestive of Crohn's disease. Radiological investigations showed thickening and narrowing of the terminal ileum, consistent with Crohn's disease. However, during exploratory laparotomy, a large phytobezoar was found obstructing the terminal ileum. Partial resection of the small bowel with removal of the phytobezoar was performed. Histopathological examination confirmed the diagnosis of a phytobezoar composed of undigested plant material. The patient's symptoms resolved postoperatively, and he remained asymptomatic on follow-up. This case highlights the importance of considering bezoars as a differential diagnosis in patients presenting with symptoms mimicking Crohn's disease, especially in those with a history of excessive fiber intake or previous gastric surgery.

Child care practices with respect to acute respiratory tract infection in a poor, urban community in Nigeria. This study aimed to investigate child care practices relating to acute respiratory tract infection (ARTI) in a poor, urban community in Nigeria. A total of 200 caregivers of children aged 2 months to 5 years were surveyed using a structured questionnaire. The majority of caregivers were mothers (87.5%) and had completed secondary education (70.5%). The study found that 95% of caregivers practiced home remedies as the first line of treatment for ARTI, including the use of herbs, steam inhalation, and honey. Only 21% sought medical care as the first response. Low socioeconomic status, lack of awareness, and cultural beliefs were identified as factors influencing these practices. Furthermore, the study revealed that 68% of caregivers engaged in inadequate hand hygiene practices. These findings highlight the need for targeted educational interventions addressing misconceptions, promoting appropriate healthcare-seeking behaviors, and emphasizing the importance of hand hygiene in preventing ARTI in this vulnerable population.

Pathogenesis of antigen-induced arthritis in mice deficient in neutrophil elastase and cathepsin G. Antigen-induced arthritis (AIA) is an inflammatory disorder characterized by joint inflammation, cartilage destruction, and bone erosion. Neutrophil elastase and cathepsin G are two serine proteases implicated in the pathogenesis of AIA. To further understand their role, we induced AIA in mice deficient in both neutrophil elastase and cathepsin G. Compared to wild-type mice, the knockout mice exhibited reduced joint swelling, decreased synovial inflammation, and lower levels of pro-inflammatory cytokines. Histological examination revealed less cartilage destruction and bone erosion in the knockout mice. Additionally, there was a significant reduction in neutrophil infiltration into the joint space. Our findings suggest that neutrophil elastase and cathepsin G play important roles in the development and progression of AIA, possibly through their involvement in synovial inflammation, cytokine production, and neutrophil recruitment. Targeting these proteases may hold therapeutic potential for the treatment of AIA.

Prospective payment system and impairment at discharge. The prospective payment system (PPS) is a reimbursement method used in healthcare to determine and allocate payments for hospital services based on predetermined rates. This study aimed to investigate the impact of PPS on impairments at discharge in a cohort of patients admitted to a rehabilitation hospital. Chart reviews were conducted on 100 patients who underwent inpatient rehabilitation and were discharged under the PPS system. Impairments were assessed using the Functional Independence Measure (FIM). Results showed a significant increase in the number of patients with impairments at discharge compared to admission, with the most common impairments being motor and cognitive deficits. These findings suggest that the PPS system may contribute to premature discharge and insufficient rehabilitation for patients with impairments. Further research is warranted to explore strategies for optimizing rehabilitation outcomes and ensuring adequate healthcare delivery for patients under the PPS system.

Flow cytometric DNA content of adenoid cystic carcinoma of submandibular gland.  Correlation of histologic features and prognosis. We investigated the flow cytometric DNA content of adenoid cystic carcinoma (ACC) of the submandibular gland and its correlation with histologic features and prognosis. Thirty-five cases of ACC were analyzed using propidium iodide staining and flow cytometry. The DNA histograms showed that 13 cases were diploid and 22 cases were aneuploid. When correlating the DNA ploidy status with histologic features, we found that aneuploid tumors were more likely to exhibit solid growth patterns and necrosis, while diploid tumors showed a higher prevalence of tubular and cribriform growth patterns. Additionally, patients with aneuploid tumors had worse overall survival rates compared to those with diploid tumors. These findings suggest that flow cytometric DNA content analysis in ACC could provide valuable prognostic information and aid in guiding treatment strategies.

Compressive neuropathy of spinal nerve roots. Compressive neuropathy of spinal nerve roots is a condition characterized by the compression or impingement of nerve roots in the spinal canal, leading to neurological symptoms. This retrospective study aimed to evaluate the incidence and clinical characteristics of compressive neuropathy of spinal nerve roots in patients with radiculopathy. A total of 100 patients with radiculopathy were included, and their medical records were analyzed. The study found that compressive neuropathy of spinal nerve roots accounted for 32% of all radiculopathy cases. Patients presented with varying degrees of sensory and motor deficits, along with radiating pain in the affected dermatomes. The most common etiology of compressive neuropathy was spinal disc herniation, followed by spinal stenosis. Prompt diagnosis and appropriate management are crucial to improve outcomes in patients with compressive neuropathy of spinal nerve roots. Further prospective studies are warranted to better understand the pathogenesis and optimal treatment approaches for this condition.

Prognostic significance of proteinuria one year after onset of diarrhea-associated hemolytic-uremic syndrome. This study aims to evaluate the prognostic significance of proteinuria one year after the onset of diarrhea-associated hemolytic-uremic syndrome (D+HUS). A total of 120 patients with D+HUS were included in the study and were followed up for one year. Proteinuria was assessed through urine analysis and was categorized as absent, mild, moderate, or severe. The main outcome measures were the occurrence of chronic kidney disease (CKD) and renal function decline. Results showed that proteinuria was present in 63% of the patients at one year after D+HUS onset. Patients with proteinuria had a significantly higher risk of CKD development and renal function decline compared to those without proteinuria. Additionally, the severity of proteinuria was associated with a higher risk of adverse renal outcomes. Therefore, proteinuria at one year after D+HUS onset could serve as a prognostic marker for identifying patients at risk for CKD and renal function decline.

Vaginal epithelial abnormalities in patients with CIN: clinical and pathological features and management. Vaginal epithelial abnormalities, specifically in patients with cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN), have significant clinical and pathological features which require proper management. This study aimed to evaluate and describe these abnormalities, their clinical presentation, histological characteristics, and appropriate management strategies. A total of 50 patients with CIN and associated vaginal epithelial abnormalities were included in the study. Clinical examination revealed various presentations, including vaginal discharge, itching, or bleeding. Histopathological analysis of vaginal biopsies showed dysplastic changes in the epithelium, ranging from mild to severe. These abnormalities were managed through a multidisciplinary approach, including close monitoring, treatment of CIN, and addressing any associated infections or inflammatory conditions. The results of this study highlight the importance of identifying and managing vaginal epithelial abnormalities in patients with CIN to ensure optimal patient care and reduce the risk of disease progression.

Effect of exposure of miners to aluminium powder. The effect of exposure to aluminium powder on miners was evaluated in this study. A total of 100 miners were assessed for various health outcomes related to aluminium exposure. The average duration of exposure was 5 years. The results showed that miners with high levels of aluminium exposure had increased respiratory symptoms such as coughing, wheezing, and shortness of breath. They also had higher rates of bronchitis and reduced lung function compared to those with low levels of exposure. Additionally, miners with prolonged exposure to aluminium powder had a higher risk of developing lung cancer. These findings highlight the potential health risks associated with aluminium exposure in miners and emphasize the need for proper protective measures in the mining industry to prevent adverse health effects in workers.
